The properties of self-assembled mol. layers (SAMs) on weakly interacting substrates depend on a delicate balance between intermol. and mol.-substrate interactions. In this paper, combining STM expts. and first principle calcns., we study 1,3,5-triazine layers grown on both graphite and G/Pt(111). We have carried out ab initio DFT calcns. trying std. and hybrids functionals as well as different approaches for the van der Waals (vdW) interactions to fully characterize the intermol.-H-bonds and vdW- and mol.-substrate-vdW attraction and Pauli repulsion-interactions. Our results confirm that, regarding the SAM formation, the mol.-substrate interaction is strong enough to fix a relative mol.-substrate orientation even though the intermol. interaction, which fixes the triangular lattice symmetry of the SAM, is larger. This game between these two interactions explains the appearance of very large moir´e patterns between SAM and substrate. However, our simulations, even testing several approaches for the vdW and XC interactions, do not reproduce neither the value of diffusion barriers nor differences between substrates found in the expts.

In this work, a comparative study between three carbon materials has been carried out to investigate the impact of the micro/mesoporous structure of the carbon substrate on their adsorption capabilities. The study included two com. carbons: Darco KB-G (AC), and Vulcan XC-72R (VC). The third carbon material was a mesoporous material (MC), with tailored micro/mesoporous structure and surface area obtained by carbonization of a resorcinol-formaldehyde (RF) polymer gel using both soft and hard template materials. Melamine was used as a model adsorbate in both acid and alk. solns. For all carbons, melamine adsorption was found to be pH dependent with higher adsorption from alk. solns. than from acidic solns. To the best of our knowledge, these are the first reported values for the adsorption of melamine to these carbon materials. Adsorption data obtained using the Langmuir model were compared with theor. studies involving melamine as a building block in the self-assembly of mol. structures on carbon substrates, and analyzed using the results of several characterization studies carried out as part of this research work, some of which include nitrogen and CO2 adsorption isotherms, Raman spectroscopy, powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), XPS, and transmission electron microscopy (TEM).

Mono- or di-triphenylphosphonium-conjugated dicyanostilbene derivs. 1 and 2 formed spherical structures with diams. of ca. 27 and 56.5 nm, resp., through π-π interaction between dicyanostilbene groups. Self-assembled 1 showed strong fluorescent emission upon the addn. of 1O2 and ClO- compared to other ROS (O2-, •OH, NO, TBHP, H2O2, GSH), metal ions (K+, Na+), and amino acids (cysteine and histidine). Upon addn. of 1O2 and ClO-, the spherical structure of 1 changed to a fiber structure (8-nm wide; 300-nm long). Upon addn. of 1O2 and ClO-, the chem. structural conversion of 1 was detd. by FAB-Mass, NMR, IR and Zeta potential anal., and the strong emission of the self-assembled 1 was due to an aggregation-induced emission enhancement. This self-assembled material was the first for selective ROS as a fluorescence turn-on probe. Thus, a nanostructure change-derived turn-on sensing strategy for 1O2 and ClO- may offer a new approach to developing methods for specific guest mols. in biol. and environmental subjects.

Designing small-mol. org. redox-active materials, with potential applications in energy storage, has received considerable interest of late. Herein, we report on the synthesis, characterization, and application of two rigid chiral triangles, each of which consist of non-identical pyromellitic diimide (PMDI) and naphthalene diimide (NDI)-based redox-active units. 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopic investigations in soln. confirm the lower symmetry (C2 point group) assocd. with these two isosceles triangles. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses reveal their rigid triangular prism-like geometries. Unlike previously investigated equilateral triangle contg. three identical NDI subunits, both isosceles triangles do not choose to form one-dimensional supramol. nanotubes by dint of [C-H···O] interaction-driven columnar stacking. The rigid isosceles triangle, composed of one NDI and two PMDI subunits, forms-in the presence of N,N-dimethylformamide-two different types of intermol. NDI-NDI and NDI-PMDI π-π stacked dimers with opposite helicities in the solid state. Cyclic voltammetry reveals that both isosceles triangles can accept reversibly up to six electrons. Continuous-wave ESR and electron-nuclear double-resonance spectroscopic investigations, supported by d. functional theory calcns., on the single-electron reduced radical anions of the isosceles triangles confirm the selective sharing of unpaired electrons among adjacent redox-active NDI subunit(s) within both mols. The isosceles triangles have been employed as electrode-active materials in org. rechargeable lithium-ion batteries. The evaluation of the structure-performance relationships of this series of diimide-based triangles reveals that the increase in the no. of NDI subunits, replacing PMDI ones, within the mols. improves the electrochem. cell performance of the batteries.

The deterioration of rubber composites filled with different types of fillers was analyzed to det. the influence of cyclic high-pressure hydrogen exposure. The mech. properties of acrylonitrile butadiene rubber (NBR) unfilled and filled with carbon black or silica were evaluated. The storage modulus of the silica-filled NBR decreased in the rubbery state as the no. of exposures increased, while those of the unfilled and carbon black-filled NBR did not change. Changes in the chem. structure such as hydrogenation or chain scission were not detected in the solid state NMR spectra of the exposed composites. However, deterioration of the filler-gel structure formed at the interface of the filler and polymer was obsd. in the silica-filled NBR. Fracture of this filler-gel structure occurred due to fatigue in the silica-filled NBR resulting from a redn. of the elastic storage modulus caused by cyclic high-pressure hydrogen exposure.

Poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) has been widely utilized in scientific research and the manufg. industry for its unique piezoelec. properties. In the past few decades, the vibrational spectra of PVDF polymorphic polymers via FTIR (Fourier transform IR spectroscopy) have been extensively investigated and documented. However, reports on the anal. of α,β and γ phases often have conflicting views based on measured data. In this work, we analyze the FTIR vibrational bands of PVDF materials fabricated by different processes with detailed XRD (X-ray diffraction) characterization to identify the structural α,β and γ phases. By examg. the results in this work and extensively reviewing published research reports in the literature, a universal phase identification procedure using only the FTIR results is proposed and validated. Specifically, this procedure can differentiate the three phases by checking the bands around 763 and/or 614, 1275, and 1234 cm-1 for the α,β and γ phases, resp. The rule for assignment of the 840* and 510* cm-1 bands is provided for the first time and an integrated quantification methodol. for individual β and γ phase in mixed systems is also demonstrated.

Addressed herein was a facile and low-cost approach to endow hydrophobic polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) membranes with reliable hydrophilicity and antifouling properties. Porous asym. hydrophilic membranes with tunable morphol. were facilely fabricated via phase inversion using an aq. soln. of graphene oxide (GO) as the coagulation bath. An increment in pore size and surface roughness was obsd. for membranes treated by a GO/water-coagulation bath (GB). The bovine serum albumin rejection of GB-treated membranes increased by 38.99% when the concn. of GO in the coagulation bath was 0.5 g L-1. The contact angle of membranes decreased from 75.9° to 58.8° and the water flux increased by 140% when the dosage of GO was 2 g L-1. Furthermore, fouling resistances of membranes revealed that GB-treated membranes had a higher flux recovery ratio (85.7%) than pristine PVDF (43.3%). Meanwhile, the protein adsorption of GB-treated membranes was decreased by 69.3% compared with that of pristine PVDF membranes. The cost of the membranes can be lowered by using a GB approach compared with GO-mixed matrix membranes because of the reusability of GO in a coagulation bath. This research presented an effective method to tailor membrane performance via GB rather than embedding GO in the membrane matrix.

Carbon Nanotubes (CNTs) are considered alternative materials for the design of advanced drug and gene delivery vectors. However, the mechanism responsible for the cellular membrane intake of CNTs is not well understood. In the present study, we show how multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) owning different surface properties, interact with giant unilamellar vesicles (GUVs), a simple model system for cellular membranes. In particular, we want to address the hydrophilic/hydrophobic interactions between MWCNTs and lipid membranes and the subsequent mech. properties changes of the systems. In order to elucidate this interaction, we made the following chem. modifications on MWCNTs: oxidized MWCNTs (ox-MWCNTs) displaying reduced hydrophobic surface character, pristine MWCNTs (p-MWCNTs), and alkyl functionalized MWCNTs (alk-MWCNTs) exhibiting enhanced hydrophobic surface properties, were put in contact with GUVs and obsd. by confocal microscopy. Our observations revealed that the interaction between the CNTs and GUVs depends on the type of chem. functionalization: ox-MWCNTs remain at the membrane interacting with the polar head of the phospholipids, p-MWCNTs internalize GUVs spontaneously, and alk-MWCNTs persist inside the membrane. The mech. properties of
[email protected]
systems were measured using the electrodeformation method, which shows an increased bending stiffness (κ) of the GUVs as MWCNTs concn. increases. High concns. of p-MWCNTs and alk-MWCNTs induced vesicle adhesion; p-MWCNTs produced a considerable redn. in the av. size of the GUVs, while alk-MWCNTs form complex stable structures inside the membrane. The statistical analyses of the exptl. results are compared with available computer simulations. The picture emerging from our results is that the interaction between GUVs and MWCNTs is due mainly to hydrophobicity.

Here, we report the effect of carbon nanotube (CNT) addn. on the electrochem. properties of LiNi0.6Co0.2Mn0.2O2 (NCM622) cathodes. By varying the CNT content from 0 to 2 wt% in the total wt. percentage (2 wt%) of conducting agents contg. carbon black, the rate capability and cycling performance are examd. The limiting factors affecting the electrochem. performance are probed by using electrochem. impedance spectroscopy and pulse polarization measurements. The results show that as the CNT content increases, the elec. cond. of the electrode decreases and the porosity increases. The addn. of 1 wt% CNT gives rise to the best rate and cycling properties for the NCM622 electrodes. The pulse measurements reveal that the CNT addn. mitigates the concn. polarization upon charging/discharging at high current rates owing to the evolved micrometer-scale pores in the electrodes, thereby leading to better rate capability. The post-mortem anal. on the electrodes discharged at a high current rate by time-of-flight secondary ion mass spectroscopy mapping show that the CNT addn. allows facile Li-ion transport from the electrolyte side into the NCM lattice, even in the vicinity of the bottom region (current collector side), which strongly corroborates the pulse polarization results. These findings suggest that the use of CNTs as a conducting agent is effective in improving the electrochem. performance of Ni-rich cathodes.

Biomimetic dopamine-conjugated polyaspartamides as novel adhesive materials were synthesized and characterized. These modified polyaspartamides contain three different groups combined with dopamine (DOPA), i.e., γ-amino butyric acid (GABA), ethanolamine (EA) and octylamine (OA), which are referred to as PolyAspAm (DOPA/GABA), PolyAspAm(DOPA/EA) and PolyAspAm(DOPA/OA), resp. These three water-swollen polymer glues show good adhesion (0.1~ 0.4 MPa) with various daily-life materials (aluminum foil, glass and paper) as well as some plastic substrates (PET and PMMA). Compared to the polymers with more hydrophilic groups (GABA and EA), the polymer glue with the hydrophobic alkyl group (OA) exhibited higher adhesive strength values on most substrates. In addn., when applied to biol. porcine skin, these glues demonstrated adhesion of values of 15~ 20 kPa with EA- and OA-conjugated polymers. These results suggest the great potential of dopamine-modified polyaspartamides as versatile and efficient polymeric glues for industrial and biomedical applications.

We utilized d. functional theory to examine HF generation in lithium-ion battery electrolytes from reactions between H2O and the decompn. products of three electrolyte additives: LiPF6, LiPOF4, and LiAsF6. Decompn. of these additives produces PF5, AsF5, and POF3 along with LiF ppts. We found PF5 and AsF5 react with H2O in two sequential steps to form two HF mols. and POF3 and AsOF3, resp. PF5 (or AsF5) complexes with H2O and undergoes ligand exchange to form HF and PF4OH (AsF4OH) with an activation barrier of 114.2 (30.5) kJ/mol and reaction enthalpy of 14.6 (-11.3) kJ/mol. The ethylene carbonate (EC) electrolyte forms a Lewis acid-base complex with the PF4OH (AsF4OH) product, reducing the barrier to HF formation. Reactions of POF3 were examd. and are not characterized by complexation of POF3 with H2O or EC, while PF5 and AsF5 complex favorably with H2O and EC. HF formation from POF3 occurs with a reaction enthalpy of -3.8 kJ/mol and a 157.7 kJ/mol barrier, 43.5 kJ/mol higher than forming HF from PF5. HF generation in electrolytes employing LiPOF4 should be significantly lower than those using LiPF6 or LiAsF6 and LiPOF4 should be further investigated as an alternative electrolyte additive.

A new synthetic route was carried out via a one-pot reaction to prep. a novel series of amidine/amidinate cobalt complexes 8-10 by mixing ligand 2 (6-pyridin-2-yl-[1,3,5]-triazine-2,4-diamine) with Co(II) in acetonitrile or benzonitrile. A change of solvent from methanol (used in complex 7, previously reported) to nitrile solvents (MeCN and PhCN) led to the in situ incorporation of the amidine group, ultimately forming 8-10. So far, this is a unique method reported to introduce amidine/amidinate groups into a pyridinyl-substituted diaminotriazine complex. Remarkably, the single crystal x-ray diffraction study (SCXRD) of these new compds. reveals assocns. involving Janus DATamidine and Janus DATamidinate. A mechanism is proposed to explain the formation of amidine/amidinate groups by studying the single crystal structures of the possible intermediates 11 and 12 where the cobalt ion acts as a template. These amidine/amidinate cobalt complexes were used as a model to assess the photocatalytic activity for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). Complexes 9 and 10 show a 74% and 86% enhancement, resp., of the catalytic activity towards the HER compared to complex 7. This highlights the structure-property relation. By examg. the novel cobalt complexes described here, the authors discovered the following: (i) a method to introduce an amidine group into a pyridine DAT-based complex, (ii) the efficiency of amidine complexes to form multiple hydrogen bonds to direct the mol. organization, (iii) the plausible mechanism of formation of amidines based on the SCXRD study, (iv) the modification of the final structure and hence the final properties by varying the reaction conditions, and (v) the utility of amidine complexes towards photocatalytic HER activity. A one-pot reaction of pyridinyl-substituted diaminotriazines and cobalt salt led to a novel series of amidine/amidinate cobalt complexes with enhanced photocatalytic HER efficiency. A mechanism is proposed by studying the single crystal structure of a reactive intermediate.

Structural and interfacial instability of the LiCoO2 cathode under a voltage exceeding 4.5 V (vs Li/Li+) severely hinders its practical applications for high-energy-d. lithium batteries. Herein, a modified electrolyte with nitriles (suberonitrile or 1,3,6-hexanetricarbonitrile) and fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) coadditives is demonstrated to form an ultrathin and uniform interface layer on LiCoO2 cathode under a synergetic effect. As such, LiCoO2/Li cells display excellent cyclability at a cutoff voltage of 4.6 V with a capacity retention over 72% after 300 cycles and 60% after 200 cycles at 30 and 55°C, resp., even achieving operation at a high current rate (10 C) upon 500 cycles as compared to the controls with fast-falling capacity to zero. Furthermore, an adsorption-coordination mechanism between nitriles and cobalt and synergetic effect of coadditives are explored by the alliance of spectroscopic anal. and theor. calcns. The contributed lone-pairs on the N 2p orbital of nitriles in coordination lowers the real oxidn. state of Co3+/4+ so that it decreases its catalysis on electrolytes, and the synergy from nitrile-derived species regulates FEC to form an LiF-contg. electron-insulated interface layer. This work shares a new insight to nitriles with the synergy of coadditives and paves a way to refine (ultra)high-voltage LiCoO2 cathode for high-energy-d. energy storages.

A review. Metal oxides have been of great importance to the development of energy conversion and storage technologies including heterojunction solar cells, Li-ion batteries, and electrocatalysts/photocatalysts for water splitting and CO2 redn. The role of metal oxides in these devices has been diverse, from charge transport layers to catalytic surfaces to protective blocking layers. Understanding the fundamental structural and electronic properties of these materials will continue to allow for advancement in the field of renewable energy. Electrochem. impedance spectroscopy (EIS) is one of the most utilized methods to characterize these electrodes in the context of energy applications. The utility of EIS stems from its ability to differentiate multiple interfaces (i.e., solid/electrolyte, solid/solid) within devices on the basis of their frequency response to a modulated potential and the subsequent decoupling of resistive and capacitive circuit components. In this review, the fundamental theory of EIS is first described with a phys. and math. basis, followed by a discussion of equiv. circuit modeling. The review then covers examples from the literature where EIS has been particularly important in the understanding of electronic properties related to metal oxide electrodes within energy conversion and storage devices. A specific focus is placed on metal oxides that are used as heterojunction solar cells, ion batteries, and photocatalysts/electrocatalysts. Common themes are discussed within each application such as the study of electron and hole diffusion in solar cells, the dependence of recombination reactions and catalysis on surface defect/trap states for solar cells and photocatalysts, and the formation of passivation layers at the solid electrolyte interface in Li-ion batteries.

The performance of the graphite/LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 cells cycled to 4.8 V (vs. Li/Li+) with 1.0M LiPF6 in ethylene carbonate/Et Me carbonate (3:7 vol. ratio) with and without added lithium bis(oxalato)borate (LiBOB) (1.5 and 2.5 wt.%) at 25° and 55° has been investigated. The initial discharge capacity of the cells with added LiBOB is slightly lower than the cells without added LiBOB. However, after 30 cycles at 55°, the cells with std. electrolyte suffer poor capacity retention (20%). The cells with 1.5% or 2.5% LiBOB have good cycling stability at 55° with 63 and 69% capacity retention, resp., after 30 cycles. The cells contg. added LiBOB also have better coulombic efficiency and lower impedance after cycling at 55°. Ex-situ surface anal. of both the anode and the cathode extd. from graphite/LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 cells was conducted via a combination of XPS, SEM, TEM with EDX, and ICP-MS. The improved cycling performance with added LiBOB can be attributed to the inhibition of electrolyte decompn. at the electrode surfaces and inhibition of Mn and Ni dissoln. from the cathode and deposition on the anode upon cycling at high voltage and elevated temp.

Replacement of precious noble metal catalysts with low-cost, non-noble heterogeneous catalysts for chemoselective redn. and reductive coupling of nitro compds. holds tremendous promise for the clean synthesis of nitrogencontaining chems. We report a robust cobalt-nitrogen/carbon (Co-Nx/C-800-AT) catalyst for the redn. and reductive coupling of nitro compds. into amines and their derivates. The Co-Nx/C-800-ATcatalyst was prepd. by the pyrolysis of cobalt phthalocyanine-silica colloid composites and the subsequent removal of silica template and cobalt nanoparticles. The Co-Nx/C-800-AT catalyst showed extremely high activity, chemoselectivity, and stability toward the redn. of nitro compds. with H♂, affording full conversion and >97% selectivity in water after 1.5 h at 110°C and under a H♂ pressure of 3.5 bar for all cases. The hydrogenation of nitrobenzene over the Co-Nx/C-800-AT catalyst can even be smoothly performed under very mild conditions (40°C and a H♂ pressure of 1 bar) with an aniline yield of 98.7%. Moreover, the Co-Nx/C-800-AT catalyst has high activity toward the transfer hydrogenation of nitrobenzene into aniline and the reductive coupling of nitrobenzene into other derivates with high yields. These processes were carried out in an environmentally friendly manner without base and ligands.

Quantitative probe of the transition metal redox in battery electrodes through soft X-ray absorption spectroscopy
Li, Qinghao; Qiao, Ruimin; Wray, L. Andrew; Chen, Jun; Zhuo, Zengqing; Chen, Yanxue; Yan, Shishen; Pan, Feng; Hussain, Zahid; Yang, Wanli

Most battery pos. electrodes operate with a 3d transition-metal (TM) reaction center. A direct and quant. probe of the TM states upon electrochem. cycling is valuable for understanding the detailed cycling mechanism and charge diffusion in the electrodes, which is related with many practical parameters of a battery. This review includes a comprehensive summary of our recent demonstrations of five different types of quant. anal. of the TM states in battery electrodes based on soft x-ray absorption spectroscopy and multiplet calcns. In LiFePO4, a system of a well-known two-phase transformation type, the TM redox could be strictly detd. through a simple linear combination of the two end-members. In Mn-based compds., the Mn states could also be quant. evaluated, but a set of ref. spectra with all the three possible Mn valences needs to be deliberately selected and considered in the fitting. Although the fluorescence signals suffer the self-absorption distortion, the multiplet calcns. could consider the distortion effect, which allows a quant. detn. of the overall Ni oxidn. state in the bulk. With the aid of multiplet calcns., one could also achieve a quasi-quant. anal. of the Co redox evolution in LiCoO2 based on the energy position of the spectroscopic peak. The benefit of multiplet calcns. is more important for studying electrode materials with TMs of mixed spin states, as exemplified by the quant. anal. of the mixed spin Na2-xFe2(CN)6 system. At the end, we showcase that such quant. anal. could provide valuable information for optimizing the electrochem. performance of Na0.44MnO2 electrodes for Na-ion batteries. The methodol. summarized in this review could be extended to other energy application systems with TM redox center for detailed anal., for example, fuel cell and catalytic materials.

It is widely accepted that for elec. vehicles to be accepted by consumers and to achieve wide market penetration, ranges of at least 500 km at an affordable cost are required. Therefore, significant improvements to lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) in terms of energy d. and cost along the battery value chain are required, while other key performance indicators, such as lifetime, safety, fast-charging ability and low-temp. performance, need to be enhanced or at least sustained. Here, we review advances and challenges in LIB materials for automotive applications, in particular with respect to cost and performance parameters. The prodn. processes of anode and cathode materials are discussed, focusing on material abundance and cost. Advantages and challenges of different types of electrolyte for automotive batteries are examd. Finally, energy densities and costs of promising battery chemistries are critically evaluated along with an assessment of the potential to fulfil the ambitious targets of elec. vehicle propulsion.

A review. Over the past several decades, the no. of elec. vehicles (EVs) has continued to increase. Projections est. that worldwide, more than 125 million EVs will be on the road by 2030. At the heart of these advanced vehicles is the lithium-ion (Li-ion) battery which provides the required energy storage. This paper presents and compares key components of Li-ion batteries and describes assocd. battery management systems, as well as approaches to improve the overall battery efficiency, capacity, and lifespan. Material and thermal characteristics are identified as crit. to battery performance. The pos. and neg. electrode materials, electrolytes and the phys. implementation of Li-ion batteries are discussed. In addn., current research on novel high energy d. batteries is presented, as well as opportunities to repurpose and recycle the batteries.

Com. lithium ion cells are now optimized for either high energy d. or high power d. There is a trade off in cell design between the power and energy requirements. A tear down protocol has been developed, to investigate the internal components and cell engineering of nine cylindrical cells, with different power-energy ratios. The cells designed for high power applications used smaller particles of the active material in both the anodes and the cathodes. The cathodes for high power cells had higher porosities, but a similar trend was not obsd. for the anodes. In terms of cell design, the coat wts. and areal capacities were lower for high power cells. The tag arrangements were the same in eight out of nine cells, with tags at each end of the anode, and one tag on the cathode. The thicknesses of the current collectors and separators were based on the best (thinnest) materials available when the cells were designed, rather than materials optimized for power or energy. To obtain high power, the resistance of each component is reduced as low as possible, and the lithium ion diffusion path lengths are minimised. This information illustrates the significant evolution of materials and components in lithium ion cells in recent years, and gives insight into designing higher power cells in the future.

Elec. and thermal characteristics of lithium-ion battery packs in elec. vehicles in different operating conditions are important in order to design the battery pack thermal management system. In this work, elec. and thermal behaviors of different size of LiFePO4 cylindrical cells are investigated under various operating conditions. The simulation results show good agreement with the exptl. data under various operating modes. Due to the large thermal resistance of layered active material in a Li-ion cell, the temp. difference in the radial direction is significantly correlated with a diam. of cell and It-rates. Compared with natural convection, strong forced convection will reduce the temp. uniformity in the cell and accelerate the thermal aging rate. Lastly, integration issues of the cells into a battery pack are discussed from mech., elec., thermal, control and monitoring, manufg. and maintenance aspects. These issues could impact the performance, cost, driving range and life cycle of the battery pack in elec. vehicles.

Increasing the areal capacity of electrodes in lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) is one of the effective ways to increase energy d. due to increased vol. fraction of active materials. However, the disassembly of cylindrical lithium iron phosphate (LFP) cell with high areal capacity electrodes at full charge state shows that the neg. electrode exhibits a gradient color from golden to silvery white, which indicates a non-uniform lithium deposition, is attributed to the unreasonable capacity matching between pos. and neg. electrodes after winding process. Inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) tests show that more irreversible lithium content is gradually distributed on neg. electrode after cycling test. Herein, inspired by this phenomenon, asym. electrodes produced by the non-uniform loading process were successfully designed to avoid non-uniform lithium deposition, which increase the capacity retention of cylindrical cell with high areal capacity electrodes from 75.8 to 91.7% at 1 C rate after 500 cycles.

The cylindrical lithium-ion battery has been widely used in 3C, xEVs, and energy storage applications and its safety sits as one of the primary barriers in the further development of its application. Among all cell components, the battery shell plays a key role to provide the mech. integrity of the lithium-ion battery upon external mech. loading. In the present study, target battery shells are extd. from com. available 18,650 NCA (Nickel Cobalt Aluminum Oxide)/graphite cells. The detailed material anal. is conducted to reveal a full understanding of the material. Then, the dynamic behavior of the battery shell material is exptl. investigated. Both theor. constitutive and numerical models have been developed, capable to describe mech. behaviors of the battery shell material upon impact loading. It is the first time to discover that the strain rate effect of the shell material shall be considered for the mech. integrity of the battery and high strength of the shell material may contribute to an early short-circuit triggering. The quant. relationship is also established between short-circuit and material strength. Results lay a solid foundation towards providing a theor. safety design guidance for the shell material choice of cylindrical lithium-ion batteries.

Compn.-gradient electrode material (CGEM) is one of the most promising materials in Li-ion battery, and this paper studies its performance from the stress anal. The finite deformation theory and the stress-induced diffusion hypothesis are adopted to establish the constitutive equations, and the nonlinear influence of finite deformation is considered. The aim is to study diffusion-induced stresses (DISs) generated in a cylindrical compn.-gradient electrode with the slope of -0.5 for Young's modulus E(R). Compared with stress distributions in a homogeneous electrode, CGEM is able to make the stress fields smaller and flatter and improve the state of charging (SOC). Then the authors change the elastic modulus of electrode materials from 10GPa to 150GPa gradually, and those advantages still exist. Finally, diffusion-induced buckling of cylindrical electrodes is analyzed and CGEMs make the cylindrical electrode more difficult to buckle. Therefore, many electrode materials can be made into CGEMs to prevent the electrode from cracking. The results can provide a theor. guidance for the design of CGEMs.

In this study, we design a hybrid thermal management system that combines liq. cooling and phase change materials (PCMs) for a battery pack of 20 Li-ion cylindrical cells. This system integrates a cold plate through which water flows into a PCM matrix composed of expanded graphite/RT44HC composites. The study aims at exploring factors that influence the temp. rise and the temp. uniformity of batteries. Expts. have been conducted to study the effect of water inlet temp. and flowrate, as well as the PCM content in a battery. The results show that the best control strategy would be to limit the water temp. less than 40°C and as close to the ambient temp. The high water flowrate reduces Tmax and ΔTplanar slightly but can significantly increase ΔTaxial and power consumption; therefore, a low flowrate is preferred. Composite PCMs with a high mass fraction of RT44HC perform better, esp. under high discharge current up to 2.9C. A numerical model has also been proposed for the hybrid thermal management system to visualise temp. distribution and heat transfer routines and for system optimization.

NCA derivs. with rock-salt domains in the structure were prepd. by a co-pptn. method and the structures of [Li1-yNiy]3(b)[Ni,Co,Al]3(a)O26(c) based on a space group of R‾3m were refined by a Rietveld method of the XRD patterns. An empirical relation is obtained to be Q = 181.4-725.5y in which Q reaches zero at y = 0.25, which is derived from not only the capacity loss owing to inactive rock-salt domains but also the polarization increase. The galvanostatic intermittent titrn. technique (GITT) measurement showed that polarization of NCA derivs. increases when the amt. of rock-salt domains is above 2%, i.e., y > 0.02, and such a relation is remarkable in the lithium insertion direction into the structure, which is ascribed to slow lithium ion mobility due to nickel ions in the lithium layers. The NCA derivs. with increased rock-salt domains of above 2% deteriorate rapidly in non-aq. lithium cells upon charge and discharge cycles, which is ascribed to the cumulative increase in polarization during charge and discharge. An extended cycling test for cylindrical lithium-ion batteries of the NCA derivs. with a graphite neg. electrode at elevated temp. was performed and the quant. relation is discussed.

Li-ion cells of the classic 18650 format are directly compared with the new 21700 format regarding electrochem., thermal, and geometrical properties. Both types of cells were reproducibly built on pilot scale with the same electrodes, separator, and electrolyte allowing a direct comparison for the first time. Internal temp. sensors give insights on the heating behavior. Similarities are found in the voltage curves and capacity fade at 1C cycling at 25 deg C. The capacity and energy increase per cell is ~ 50% from 18650 to 21700 for discharge in the range of 0.5C-3.75C. The results are compared with calcns. of electrode areas based on Archimedean spiral's arc lengths and geometrical data extd. from X-ray computed tomog. (CT) measurements. Two evaluation methods for extn. of the no. of electrode windings from CT images are compared. Calcns. are made for the winding no. as a function of the periodic winding distance (thicknesses of anode, cathode, and 2x separator) as well as on electrode curvature for both cell formats. The influences of intended extensions of the cell diam. by few μm (as obsd. in com. cylindrical cells), as well as larger formats such as 30700 on addnl. electrode windings and cell capacity are estd.

An ideal flexible battery should have high flexibility, high energy d. and high power d. simultaneously, which are often in conflict with each other. A review. The research in high performance flexible lithium ion batteries (FLIBs) thrives with the increasing demand in novel flexible electronics such as wearable devices and implantable medical kits. FLIBs share the same working mechanism with traditional LIBs. Meanwhile, FLIBs need to exhibit flexibility and even bendable and stretchable features. The development of FLIBs highly relies on the improvement of flexible electrodes and battery designs to achieve high performance and stability under mech. deformation. In this review, recent advances and progress on the development of FLIBs are concerned. Two specific research strategies of FLIBs are discussed in detail: prepn. of flexible battery components (including electrodes, current collectors, and electrolytes) and flexible structure designs or assembly methods of FLIBs. Finally, challenges and perspectives for developing high performance FLIBs are presented.

Tremendous efforts have been devoted to the development of electrode materials, electrolytes, and separators of energy-storage devices to address the fundamental needs of emerging technologies such as elec. vehicles, artificial intelligence, and virtual reality. However, binders, as an important component of energy-storage devices, are yet to receive similar attention. Polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) has been the dominant binder in the battery industry for decades despite several well-recognized drawbacks, i.e., limited binding strength due to the lack of chem. bonds with electroactive materials, insufficient mech. properties, and low electronic and lithium-ion conductivities. The limited binding function cannot meet inherent demands of emerging electrode materials with high capacities such as silicon anodes and sulfur cathodes. To address these concerns, in this review we divide the binding between active materials and binders into two major mechanisms: mech. interlocking and interfacial binding forces. We review existing and emerging binders, binding technol. used in energy-storage devices (including lithium-ion batteries, lithium-sulfur batteries, sodium-ion batteries, and supercapacitors), and state-of-the-art mech. characterization and computational methods for binder research. Finally, we propose prospective next-generation binders for energy-storage devices from the mol. level to the macro level. Functional binders will play crucial roles in future high-performance energy-storage devices.

Flexible energy-storage devices have attracted growing attention with the fast development of bendable electronic systems. However, it still remains a challenge to find reliable electrode materials with both high mech. flexibility/toughness and excellent electron and lithium-ion cond. This paper reports the fabrication and characterization of highly porous, stretchable, and conductive polymer nanocomposites embedded with carbon nanotubes (CNTs) for application in flexible lithium-ion batteries. The systematic optimization of the porous morphol. is performed by controllably inducing the phase sepn. of polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA) in polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) and removing PMMA, in order to generate well-controlled pore networks. It is demonstrated that the porous CNT-embedded PDMS nanocomposites are capable of good electrochem. performance with mech. flexibility, suggesting these nanocomposites could be outstanding anode candidates for use in flexible lithium-ion batteries. The optimization of the pore size and the vol. fraction provides higher capacity by nearly seven-fold compared to a nonporous nanocomposite.

The emergence of wearable electronics puts batteries closer to the human skin, exacerbating the need for battery materials that are robust, highly ionically conductive, and stretchable. Herein, we introduce a supramolecular design as an effective strategy to overcome the canonical tradeoff between mechanical robustness and ionic conductivity in polymer electrolytes. The supramolecular lithium ion conductor utilizes orthogonally functional H-bonding domains and ion-conducting domains to create a polymer electrolyte with unprecedented toughness (29.3 MJ m(-3)) and high ionic conductivity (1.2 × 10(-4) S cm(-1) at 25 °C). Implementation of the supramolecular ion conductor as a binder material allows for the creation of stretchable lithium-ion battery electrodes with strain capability of over 900% via a conventional slurry process. The supramolecular nature of these battery components enables intimate bonding at the electrode-electrolyte interface. Combination of these stretchable components leads to a stretchable battery with a capacity of 1.1 mAh cm(-2) that functions even when stretched to 70% strain. The method reported here of decoupling ionic conductivity from mechanical properties opens a promising route to create high-toughness ion transport materials for energy storage applications.

Lithium-ion batteries with ever-increasing energy densities are needed for batteries for advanced devices and all-elec. vehicles. Silicon was highlighted as a promising anode material because of its superior specific capacity. During repeated charge-discharge cycles, silicon undergoes huge vol. changes. This limits cycle life via particle pulverization and an unstable electrode-electrolyte interface, esp. when the particle sizes are in the micrometer range. We show that the incorporation of 5 wt. % polyrotaxane to conventional polyacrylic acid binder imparts extraordinary elasticity to the polymer network originating from the ring sliding motion of polyrotaxane. This binder combination keeps even pulverized silicon particles coalesced without disintegration, enabling stable cycle life for silicon microparticle anodes at com.-level areal capacities.

Many potential applications are proposed for carbon nanotubes, including conductive and high-strength composites; energy storage and energy conversion devices sensors; field emission displays and radiation sources; hydrogen storage media; and nanometer-sized semiconductor devices, probes, and interconnects. Some of these applications are now realized in products. Others are demonstrated in early to advanced devices and one, hydrogen storage, is clouded by controversy. Nanotube cost, polydispersity in nanotube type, and limitations in processing and assembly methods are important barriers for some applications of single-walled nanotubes.

C nanotube wiring may be extremely light and mech. stronger and more efficient in transferring high frequency signals than any conventional conducting material, being cost-effective simultaneously. We demonstrate a highly durable and stretchable carbon nanotube (CNT)-polymer transparent conductive film by utilizing polyacrylic acid wrapping to simultaneously disperse and dope CNTs. This novel strategy not only enables an easy and industrially scalable process where neither removal of dispersant nor further doping is necessary, but also results in a boost in the cond. and durability, and correspondingly it provides infinite versatility for various applications. A significant improvement in cond. being comparable to acid doping is achieved through a hybrid structure in which a polyacrylic acid monolayer helically and partially wraps the CNT surface. The optimum films show sheet resistances of 150 and 60 Ω per square at 91% and 84% optical transmittances, resp. Notably, the sheet resistances of hybrid films remain almost const. after aging tests under conditions of 85 °C and 85% relative humidity for more than 3000 h, and bending and stretching tests of more than 1 million cycles, suggesting outstanding long-term stability and record-high flexibility and stretchability. Therefore, the highly transparent conductive film, combined with excellent long-term and mech. durability, and surprisingly easy processability, opens new routes for next-generation wearable electronics and bioelectronics.

Debundling and dispersion of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) in polymer solns. play a major role in the prepn. of carbon nanofibers due to early effects on interfacial ordering and mech. properties. A roadblock toward ultrastrong fibers is the difficulty to achieve homogeneous dispersions of CNTs in polyacrylonitrile (PAN) and poly(Me methacrylate) (PMMA) precursor solns. in solvents such as DMSO, N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMAc), and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF). In this contribution, mol. dynamics simulations with accurate interat. potentials for graphitic materials that include virtual π electrons are reported to analyze the interaction of pristine single wall CNTs with the solvents and polymer solns. at 25 °C. The results explain the barriers toward dispersion of SWCNTs and quantify CNT-solvent, polymer-solvent, as well as CNT-polymer interactions in at. detail. Debundling of CNTs is overall endothermic and unfavorable with dispersion energies of +20 to +30 mJ/m2 in the pure solvents, + 20 to +40 mJ/m2 in PAN solns., and +20 to +60 mJ/m2 in PMMA solns. Differences arise due to mol. geometry, polar, van der Waals, and CH-π interactions. Among the pure solvents, DMF restricts CNT dispersion less due to the planar geometry and stronger van der Waals interactions. PAN and PMMA interact favorably with the pure solvents with dissoln. energies of -0.7 to -1.1 kcal per mol. monomer and -1.5 to -2.2 kcal per mol. monomer, resp. Adsorption of PMMA onto CNTs is stronger than that of PAN in all solvents as the mol. geometry enables more van der Waals contacts between alkyl groups and the CNT surface. Polar side groups in both polymers prefer interactions with the polar solvents. Higher polymer concns. in soln. lead to polymer aggregation via alkyl groups and reduce adsorption onto CNTs. PAN and PMMA solns. in DMSO and dil. solns. in DMF support CNT dispersion more than other combinations whereby the polymers significantly adsorb onto CNTs in DMSO soln. The observations by mol. simulations are consistent with available exptl. data and soly. parameters and aid in the design of carbon nanofibers. The methods can be applied to other multiphase graphitic materials.

The colloidal behavior of aqueous dispersions of functionalized multiwall carbon nanotubes (F-CNTS) formed via carboxylation and polymer wrapping with polyvinyl pyrrolidone (PVP) is presented. This paper highlights elements evidencing a possibility for NBR polymer chains to react by a free-radical mechanism and to graft onto CNT surface all along the process of mech. blending of NBR with CNTs. Compared to the pure CTAB and SDS, these mixts. are more effective with the lower concns. and more individual CNTs, reflecting a synergistic effect in these mixts. The synergistic effects obsd. in mixed surfactant systems are mainly due to the electrostatic attractions between surfactant heads. In addn., the surface charge related to the colloidal stability of mixed surfactant-covered nanotubes has been characterized by means of ζ-potential measurements. The results indicate that the hydrophobic interactions between surfactant tails also give rise to the higher adsorption of surfactant mols. Furthermore, mol. dynamics (MD) simulations have been performed to provide insight about the structure of surfactant aggregates onto nanotubes and to attempt an explanation of the exptl. results. The MD simulation results indicate that the random and disordered adsorption of mixed surfactants onto carbon nanotubes may be preferred for a low surfactant concn. Our research may provide exptl. and theor. bases for using mixed surfactants to disperse CNTs, which can open an avenue for new applications of mixed surfactants.

A com. elastomer, Hydrogenated Nitrile Butadiene Rubber (HNBR), is used as a binder for Li-ion battery pos. and neg. electrodes. As the polymer as never been used before as a binder, the aim of this study is to investigate the chem. stability of HNBR with regard to the electrolyte, to show its electrochem. stability, and to demonstrate the application of these elastomers in Li-ion battery electrodes. To ensure insoly. in the electrolyte, HNBR is previously crosslinked and tensile tests are used on these films to evaluate their mech. properties. The electrochem. stability of this polymer is analyzed and validated by cyclic voltammetry. Power and cycling performances of crosslinked HNBR-based electrodes are compared to conventional ones using poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVdF). It is found that crosslinked HNBR is electrochem. stable in the potential windows studied, i.e. 1-2.2 V and 2.2-4.2 V. When used in pos. and neg. electrodes, crosslinked HNBR full-cell retains a capacity of 128 mAh.g-1 after 200 cycles, compared to 117 mAh.g-1 for conventional PVdF cells. This makes HNBR a good candidate as a binder for Li-ion batteries.

The present work demonstrates the structure-rheol. relationship of novel polyvinylidene fluoride/hydrogenated nitrile rubber blends with special ref. to the effect of mixing time, which has not been amply discussed in the literature. In between 50 and 70 wt% rubber content, a yield in complex viscosity and secondary plateau in storage modulus were discerned due to interconnected droplets-matrix morphol. manifesting the thermoplastic elastomeric nature of the blends (TPEs). Such network-like structure altered the rheol. properties like relaxation time, capillary viscosity, die swell, elastic responses of the TPE with respect to the trend as expected according to the rule of mixing. Interestingly, in the early stages of mixing, when the dispersed size was bigger, the effect of phys. network on the rheol. properties was suppressed. During dynamic vulcanization (TPV), both lower and higher frequency responses in oscillatory shear flow, steady shear rheol. properties, recoverable strain etc. have changed notably with mixing time. For example, although the complex viscosity of the TPV was higher at a lower frequency as compared to its TPE, it was significantly lower at a higher frequency at the beginning of dynamic curing; however, viscosity increased appreciably with time. A flame retardant and thermally dimensional stable membrane with high permeability and electrolyte wettability can overcome the safety issues of lithium ion batteries (LIBs) at elevated temps. In this work, a multifunctional thermoset nonwoven membrane composed of melamine formaldehyde resin (MFR) nano-fibers was prepd. by a electro-spinning method. The resultant porous nonwoven membrane possesses superior permeability, electrolyte wettability and thermally dimensional stability. Using the electrospun MFR membrane, the LiFePO4/Li battery exhibits high safety and stable cycling performance at the elevated temp. of 120 °C. Most importantly, the MFR membrane contains lone pair electron in the nitrogen element, which can chelate with Mn2+ ions and suppress their transfer across the separator. Therefore, the LiMn2O4/graphite cells with the electrospun MFR multifunctional membranes reveal an improved cycle performance even at high temp. This work demonstrated that electrospun MFR is a promising candidate material for high-safety separator of LIBs with stable cycling performance at elevated temps.

The properties of self-assembled mol. layers (SAMs) on weakly interacting substrates depend on a delicate balance between intermol. and mol.-substrate interactions. In this paper, combining STM expts. and first principle calcns., we study 1,3,5-triazine layers grown on both graphite and G/Pt(111). We have carried out ab initio DFT calcns. trying std. and hybrids functionals as well as different approaches for the van der Waals (vdW) interactions to fully characterize the intermol.-H-bonds and vdW- and mol.-substrate-vdW attraction and Pauli repulsion-interactions. Our results confirm that, regarding the SAM formation, the mol.-substrate interaction is strong enough to fix a relative mol.-substrate orientation even though the intermol. interaction, which fixes the triangular lattice symmetry of the SAM, is larger. This game between these two interactions explains the appearance of very large moir´e patterns between SAM and substrate. However, our simulations, even testing several approaches for the vdW and XC interactions, do not reproduce neither the value of diffusion barriers nor differences between substrates found in the expts.

In this work, a comparative study between three carbon materials has been carried out to investigate the impact of the micro/mesoporous structure of the carbon substrate on their adsorption capabilities. The study included two com. carbons: Darco KB-G (AC), and Vulcan XC-72R (VC). The third carbon material was a mesoporous material (MC), with tailored micro/mesoporous structure and surface area obtained by carbonization of a resorcinol-formaldehyde (RF) polymer gel using both soft and hard template materials. Melamine was used as a model adsorbate in both acid and alk. solns. For all carbons, melamine adsorption was found to be pH dependent with higher adsorption from alk. solns. than from acidic solns. To the best of our knowledge, these are the first reported values for the adsorption of melamine to these carbon materials. Adsorption data obtained using the Langmuir model were compared with theor. studies involving melamine as a building block in the self-assembly of mol. structures on carbon substrates, and analyzed using the results of several characterization studies carried out as part of this research work, some of which include nitrogen and CO2 adsorption isotherms, Raman spectroscopy, powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), XPS, and transmission electron microscopy (TEM).

A review. In this Review, the authors present recent advances in NMR and EPR spectroscopy and their application to functional polymers and supramol. systems. A complete coverage of all macromol. and supramol. systems is beyond the scope of the review. The specific systems described should be seen as examples rather than a comprehensive coverage of the field. Functionality of such polymeric and supramol. systems depends on their mol. structure (repeat unit) and the organization (architecture) of the material. This is reflected in the division of the Review into subsections based on mol. structure, selected for different architectures and functionalities. Special emphasis is given to how the information obtained from EPR and NMR relates to that obtained by other techniques.

The structure of MF-Si resins was characterized by FTIR spectroscopy, Raman spectroscopy, 1H NMR, and solid state 13C NMR. It was found that APTES moieties in MF-Si materials afforded increased hydrophobicity, water resistance, and the thermal stability was not affected. We report self-assembled novel triphenylphosphonium-conjugated dicyanostilbene-based as selective fluorescence turn-on probes for 1O2 and ClO-. Mono- or di-triphenylphosphonium-conjugated dicyanostilbene derivs. 1 and 2 formed spherical structures with diams. of ca. 27 and 56.5 nm, resp., through π-π interaction between dicyanostilbene groups. Self-assembled 1 showed strong fluorescent emission upon the addn. of 1O2 and ClO- compared to other ROS (O2-, •OH, NO, TBHP, H2O2, GSH), metal ions (K+, Na+), and amino acids (cysteine and histidine). Upon addn. of 1O2 and ClO-, the spherical structure of 1 changed to a fiber structure (8-nm wide; 300-nm long). Upon addn. of 1O2 and ClO-, the chem. structural conversion of 1 was detd. by FAB-Mass, NMR, IR and Zeta potential anal., and the strong emission of the self-assembled 1 was due to an aggregation-induced emission enhancement. This self-assembled material was the first for selective ROS as a fluorescence turn-on probe. Thus, a nanostructure change-derived turn-on sensing strategy for 1O2 and ClO- may offer a new approach to developing methods for specific guest mols. in biol. and environmental subjects.

Designing small-mol. org. redox-active materials, with potential applications in energy storage, has received considerable interest of late. Herein, we report on the synthesis, characterization, and application of two rigid chiral triangles, each of which consist of non-identical pyromellitic diimide (PMDI) and naphthalene diimide (NDI)-based redox-active units. 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopic investigations in soln. confirm the lower symmetry (C2 point group) assocd. with these two isosceles triangles. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses reveal their rigid triangular prism-like geometries. Unlike previously investigated equilateral triangle contg. three identical NDI subunits, both isosceles triangles do not choose to form one-dimensional supramol. nanotubes by dint of [C-H···O] interaction-driven columnar stacking. The rigid isosceles triangle, composed of one NDI and two PMDI subunits, forms-in the presence of N,N-dimethylformamide-two different types of intermol. NDI-NDI and NDI-PMDI π-π stacked dimers with opposite helicities in the solid state. Cyclic voltammetry reveals that both isosceles triangles can accept reversibly up to six electrons. Continuous-wave ESR and electron-nuclear double-resonance spectroscopic investigations, supported by d. functional theory calcns., on the single-electron reduced radical anions of the isosceles triangles confirm the selective sharing of unpaired electrons among adjacent redox-active NDI subunit(s) within both mols. The isosceles triangles have been employed as electrode-active materials in org. rechargeable lithium-ion batteries. The evaluation of the structure-performance relationships of this series of diimide-based triangles reveals that the increase in the no. of NDI subunits, replacing PMDI ones, within the mols. improves the electrochem. cell performance of the batteries.

The deterioration of rubber composites filled with different types of fillers was analyzed to det. the influence of cyclic high-pressure hydrogen exposure. The mech. properties of acrylonitrile butadiene rubber (NBR) unfilled and filled with carbon black or silica were evaluated. The storage modulus of the silica-filled NBR decreased in the rubbery state as the no. of exposures increased, while those of the unfilled and carbon black-filled NBR did not change. Changes in the chem. structure such as hydrogenation or chain scission were not detected in the solid state NMR spectra of the exposed composites. However, deterioration of the filler-gel structure formed at the interface of the filler and polymer was obsd. in the silica-filled NBR. Fracture of this filler-gel structure occurred due to fatigue in the silica-filled NBR resulting from a redn. of the elastic storage modulus caused by cyclic high-pressure hydrogen exposure.

Poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) has been widely utilized in scientific research and the manufg. industry for its unique piezoelec. properties. In the past few decades, the vibrational spectra of PVDF polymorphic polymers via FTIR (Fourier transform IR spectroscopy) have been extensively investigated and documented. However, reports on the anal. of α,β and γ phases often have conflicting views based on measured data. In this work, we analyze the FTIR vibrational bands of PVDF materials fabricated by different processes with detailed XRD (X-ray diffraction) characterization to identify the structural α,β and γ phases. By examg. the results in this work and extensively reviewing published research reports in the literature, a universal phase identification procedure using only the FTIR results is proposed and validated. Specifically, this procedure can differentiate the three phases by checking the bands around 763 and/or 614, 1275, and 1234 cm-1 for the α,β and γ phases, resp. The rule for assignment of the 840* and 510* cm-1 bands is provided for the first time and an integrated quantification methodol. for individual β and γ phase in mixed systems is also demonstrated.

Addressed herein was a facile and low-cost approach to endow hydrophobic polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) membranes with reliable hydrophilicity and antifouling properties. Porous asym. hydrophilic membranes with tunable morphol. were facilely fabricated via phase inversion using an aq. soln. of graphene oxide (GO) as the coagulation bath. An increment in pore size and surface roughness was obsd. for membranes treated by a GO/water-coagulation bath (GB). The bovine serum albumin rejection of GB-treated membranes increased by 38.99% when the concn. of GO in the coagulation bath was 0.5 g L-1. The contact angle of membranes decreased from 75.9° to 58.8° and the water flux increased by 140% when the dosage of GO was 2 g L-1. Furthermore, fouling resistances of membranes revealed that GB-treated membranes had a higher flux recovery ratio (85.7%) than pristine PVDF (43.3%). Meanwhile, the protein adsorption of GB-treated membranes was decreased by 69.3% compared with that of pristine PVDF membranes. The cost of the membranes can be lowered by using a GB approach compared with GO-mixed matrix membranes because of the reusability of GO in a coagulation bath. This research presented an effective method to tailor membrane performance via GB rather than embedding GO in the membrane matrix.

Carbon Nanotubes (CNTs) are considered alternative materials for the design of advanced drug and gene delivery vectors. However, the mechanism responsible for the cellular membrane intake of CNTs is not well understood. In the present study, we show how multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) owning different surface properties, interact with giant unilamellar vesicles (GUVs), a simple model system for cellular membranes. In particular, we want to address the hydrophilic/hydrophobic interactions between MWCNTs and lipid membranes and the subsequent mech. properties changes of the systems. In order to elucidate this interaction, we made the following chem. modifications on MWCNTs: oxidized MWCNTs (ox-MWCNTs) displaying reduced hydrophobic surface character, pristine MWCNTs (p-MWCNTs), and alkyl functionalized MWCNTs (alk-MWCNTs) exhibiting enhanced hydrophobic surface properties, were put in contact with GUVs and obsd. by confocal microscopy. Our observations revealed that the interaction between the CNTs and GUVs depends on the type of chem. functionalization: ox-MWCNTs remain at the membrane interacting with the polar head of the phospholipids, p-MWCNTs internalize GUVs spontaneously, and alk-MWCNTs persist inside the membrane. The mech. properties of
[email protected]
systems were measured using the electrodeformation method, which shows an increased bending stiffness (κ) of the GUVs as MWCNTs concn. increases. High concns. of p-MWCNTs and alk-MWCNTs induced vesicle adhesion; p-MWCNTs produced a considerable redn. in the av. size of the GUVs, while alk-MWCNTs form complex stable structures inside the membrane. The statistical analyses of the exptl. results are compared with available computer simulations. The picture emerging from our results is that the interaction between GUVs and MWCNTs is due mainly to hydrophobicity.

Here, we report the effect of carbon nanotube (CNT) addn. on the electrochem. properties of LiNi0.6Co0.2Mn0.2O2 (NCM622) cathodes. By varying the CNT content from 0 to 2 wt% in the total wt. percentage (2 wt%) of conducting agents contg. carbon black, the rate capability and cycling performance are examd. The limiting factors affecting the electrochem. performance are probed by using electrochem. impedance spectroscopy and pulse polarization measurements. The results show that as the CNT content increases, the elec. cond. of the electrode decreases and the porosity increases. The addn. of 1 wt% CNT gives rise to the best rate and cycling properties for the NCM622 electrodes. The pulse measurements reveal that the CNT addn. mitigates the concn. polarization upon charging/discharging at high current rates owing to the evolved micrometer-scale pores in the electrodes, thereby leading to better rate capability. The post-mortem anal. on the electrodes discharged at a high current rate by time-of-flight secondary ion mass spectroscopy mapping show that the CNT addn. allows facile Li-ion transport from the electrolyte side into the NCM lattice, even in the vicinity of the bottom region (current collector side), which strongly corroborates the pulse polarization results. These findings suggest that the use of CNTs as a conducting agent is effective in improving the electrochem. performance of Ni-rich cathodes.

Biomimetic dopamine-conjugated polyaspartamides as novel adhesive materials were synthesized and characterized. These modified polyaspartamides contain three different groups combined with dopamine (DOPA), i.e., γ-amino butyric acid (GABA), ethanolamine (EA) and octylamine (OA), which are referred to as PolyAspAm (DOPA/GABA), PolyAspAm(DOPA/EA) and PolyAspAm(DOPA/OA), resp. These three water-swollen polymer glues show good adhesion (0.1~ 0.4 MPa) with various daily-life materials (aluminum foil, glass and paper) as well as some plastic substrates (PET and PMMA). Compared to the polymers with more hydrophilic groups (GABA and EA), the polymer glue with the hydrophobic alkyl group (OA) exhibited higher adhesive strength values on most substrates. In addn., when applied to biol. porcine skin, these glues demonstrated adhesion of values of 15~ 20 kPa with EA- and OA-conjugated polymers. These results suggest the great potential of dopamine-modified polyaspartamides as versatile and efficient polymeric glues for industrial and biomedical applications.

We utilized d. functional theory to examine HF generation in lithium-ion battery electrolytes from reactions between H2O and the decompn. products of three electrolyte additives: LiPF6, LiPOF4, and LiAsF6. Decompn. of these additives produces PF5, AsF5, and POF3 along with LiF ppts. We found PF5 and AsF5 react with H2O in two sequential steps to form two HF mols. and POF3 and AsOF3, resp. PF5 (or AsF5) complexes with H2O and undergoes ligand exchange to form HF and PF4OH (AsF4OH) with an activation barrier of 114.2 (30.5) kJ/mol and reaction enthalpy of 14.6 (-11.3) kJ/mol. The ethylene carbonate (EC) electrolyte forms a Lewis acid-base complex with the PF4OH (AsF4OH) product, reducing the barrier to HF formation. Reactions of POF3 were examd. and are not characterized by complexation of POF3 with H2O or EC, while PF5 and AsF5 complex favorably with H2O and EC. HF formation from POF3 occurs with a reaction enthalpy of -3.8 kJ/mol and a 157.7 kJ/mol barrier, 43.5 kJ/mol higher than forming HF from PF5. HF generation in electrolytes employing LiPOF4 should be significantly lower than those using LiPF6 or LiAsF6 and LiPOF4 should be further investigated as an alternative electrolyte additive.

A new synthetic route was carried out via a one-pot reaction to prep. a novel series of amidine/amidinate cobalt complexes 8-10 by mixing ligand 2 (6-pyridin-2-yl-[1,3,5]-triazine-2,4-diamine) with Co(II) in acetonitrile or benzonitrile. A change of solvent from methanol (used in complex 7, previously reported) to nitrile solvents (MeCN and PhCN) led to the in situ incorporation of the amidine group, ultimately forming 8-10. So far, this is a unique method reported to introduce amidine/amidinate groups into a pyridinyl-substituted diaminotriazine complex. Remarkably, the single crystal x-ray diffraction study (SCXRD) of these new compds. reveals assocns. involving Janus DATamidine and Janus DATamidinate. A mechanism is proposed to explain the formation of amidine/amidinate groups by studying the single crystal structures of the possible intermediates 11 and 12 where the cobalt ion acts as a template. These amidine/amidinate cobalt complexes were used as a model to assess the photocatalytic activity for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). Complexes 9 and 10 show a 74% and 86% enhancement, resp., of the catalytic activity towards the HER compared to complex 7. This highlights the structure-property relation. By examg. the novel cobalt complexes described here, the authors discovered the following: (i) a method to introduce an amidine group into a pyridine DAT-based complex, (ii) the efficiency of amidine complexes to form multiple hydrogen bonds to direct the mol. organization, (iii) the plausible mechanism of formation of amidines based on the SCXRD study, (iv) the modification of the final structure and hence the final properties by varying the reaction conditions, and (v) the utility of amidine complexes towards photocatalytic HER activity. A one-pot reaction of pyridinyl-substituted diaminotriazines and cobalt salt led to a novel series of amidine/amidinate cobalt complexes with enhanced photocatalytic HER efficiency. A mechanism is proposed by studying the single crystal structure of a reactive intermediate.

Enabling Stable High-Voltage LiCoO2 Operation by Using Synergetic Interfacial Modification Strategy
Yang, Xuerui; Lin, Min; Zheng, Guorui; Wu, Jue; Wang, Xianshu; Ren, Fucheng; Zhang, Wenguang; Liao, Ying; Zhao, Weimin; Zhang, Zhongru; Xu, Ningbo; Yang, Wanli; Yang, Yong

Structural and interfacial instability of the LiCoO2 cathode under a voltage exceeding 4.5 V (vs Li/Li+) severely hinders its practical applications for high-energy-d. lithium batteries. Herein, a modified electrolyte with nitriles (suberonitrile or 1,3,6-hexanetricarbonitrile) and fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) coadditives is demonstrated to form an ultrathin and uniform interface layer on LiCoO2 cathode under a synergetic effect. As such, LiCoO2/Li cells display excellent cyclability at a cutoff voltage of 4.6 V with a capacity retention over 72% after 300 cycles and 60% after 200 cycles at 30 and 55°C, resp., even achieving operation at a high current rate (10 C) upon 500 cycles as compared to the controls with fast-falling capacity to zero. Furthermore, an adsorption-coordination mechanism between nitriles and cobalt and synergetic effect of coadditives are explored by the alliance of spectroscopic anal. and theor. calcns. The contributed lone-pairs on the N 2p orbital of nitriles in coordination lowers the real oxidn. state of Co3+/4+ so that it decreases its catalysis on electrolytes, and the synergy from nitrile-derived species regulates FEC to form an LiF-contg. electron-insulated interface layer. This work shares a new insight to nitriles with the synergy of coadditives and paves a way to refine (ultra)high-voltage LiCoO2 cathode for high-energy-d. energy storages.

Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy of Metal Oxide Electrodes for Energy Applications
Bredar, Alexandria R. C.; Chown, Amanda L.; Burton, Andricus R.; Farnum, Byron H.

CODEN:

American Chemical Society

A review. Metal oxides have been of great importance to the development of energy conversion and storage technologies including heterojunction solar cells, Li-ion batteries, and electrocatalysts/photocatalysts for water splitting and CO2 redn. The role of metal oxides in these devices has been diverse, from charge transport layers to catalytic surfaces to protective blocking layers. Understanding the fundamental structural and electronic properties of these materials will continue to allow for advancement in the field of renewable energy. Electrochem. impedance spectroscopy (EIS) is one of the most utilized methods to characterize these electrodes in the context of energy applications. The utility of EIS stems from its ability to differentiate multiple interfaces (i.e., solid/electrolyte, solid/solid) within devices on the basis of their frequency response to a modulated potential and the subsequent decoupling of resistive and capacitive circuit components. In this review, the fundamental theory of EIS is first described with a phys. and math. basis, followed by a discussion of equiv. circuit modeling. The review then covers examples from the literature where EIS has been particularly important in the understanding of electronic properties related to metal oxide electrodes within energy conversion and storage devices. A specific focus is placed on metal oxides that are used as heterojunction solar cells, ion batteries, and photocatalysts/electrocatalysts. Common themes are discussed within each application such as the study of electron and hole diffusion in solar cells, the dependence of recombination reactions and catalysis on surface defect/trap states for solar cells and photocatalysts, and the formation of passivation layers at the solid electrolyte interface in Li-ion batteries.

The performance of the graphite/LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 cells cycled to 4.8 V (vs. Li/Li+) with 1.0M LiPF6 in ethylene carbonate/Et Me carbonate (3:7 vol. ratio) with and without added lithium bis(oxalato)borate (LiBOB) (1.5 and 2.5 wt.%) at 25° and 55° has been investigated. The initial discharge capacity of the cells with added LiBOB is slightly lower than the cells without added LiBOB. However, after 30 cycles at 55°, the cells with std. electrolyte suffer poor capacity retention (20%). The cells with 1.5% or 2.5% LiBOB have good cycling stability at 55° with 63 and 69% capacity retention, resp., after 30 cycles. The cells contg. added LiBOB also have better coulombic efficiency and lower impedance after cycling at 55°. Ex-situ surface anal. of both the anode and the cathode extd. from graphite/LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 cells was conducted via a combination of XPS, SEM, TEM with EDX, and ICP-MS. The improved cycling performance with added LiBOB can be attributed to the inhibition of electrolyte decompn. at the electrode surfaces and inhibition of Mn and Ni dissoln. from the cathode and deposition on the anode upon cycling at high voltage and elevated temp.

Replacement of precious noble metal catalysts with low-cost, non-noble heterogeneous catalysts for chemoselective redn. and reductive coupling of nitro compds. holds tremendous promise for the clean synthesis of nitrogencontaining chems. We report a robust cobalt-nitrogen/carbon (Co-Nx/C-800-AT) catalyst for the redn. and reductive coupling of nitro compds. into amines and their derivates. The Co-Nx/C-800-ATcatalyst was prepd. by the pyrolysis of cobalt phthalocyanine-silica colloid composites and the subsequent removal of silica template and cobalt nanoparticles. The Co-Nx/C-800-AT catalyst showed extremely high activity, chemoselectivity, and stability toward the redn. of nitro compds. with H♂, affording full conversion and >97% selectivity in water after 1.5 h at 110°C and under a H♂ pressure of 3.5 bar for all cases. The hydrogenation of nitrobenzene over the Co-Nx/C-800-AT catalyst can even be smoothly performed under very mild conditions (40°C and a H♂ pressure of 1 bar) with an aniline yield of 98.7%. Moreover, the Co-Nx/C-800-AT catalyst has high activity toward the transfer hydrogenation of nitrobenzene into aniline and the reductive coupling of nitrobenzene into other derivates with high yields. These processes were carried out in an environmentally friendly manner without base and ligands.

Quantitative probe of the transition metal redox in battery electrodes through soft X-ray absorption spectroscopy
Li, Qinghao; Qiao, Ruimin; Wray, L. Andrew; Chen, Jun; Zhuo, Zengqing; Chen, Yanxue; Yan, Shishen; Pan, Feng; Hussain, Zahid; Yang, Wanli
Journal of Physics D: Applied Physics

),

(

CODEN:

; ISSN:
0022-3727
.

IOP Publishing Ltd.

Most battery pos. electrodes operate with a 3d transition-metal (TM) reaction center. A direct and quant. probe of the TM states upon electrochem. cycling is valuable for understanding the detailed cycling mechanism and charge diffusion in the electrodes, which is related with many practical parameters of a battery. This review includes a comprehensive summary of our recent demonstrations of five different types of quant. anal. of the TM states in battery electrodes based on soft x-ray absorption spectroscopy and multiplet calcns. In LiFePO4, a system of a well-known two-phase transformation type, the TM redox could be strictly detd. through a simple linear combination of the two end-members. In Mn-based compds., the Mn states could also be quant. evaluated, but a set of ref. spectra with all the three possible Mn valences needs to be deliberately selected and considered in the fitting. Although the fluorescence signals suffer the self-absorption distortion, the multiplet calcns. could consider the distortion effect, which allows a quant. detn. of the overall Ni oxidn. state in the bulk. With the aid of multiplet calcns., one could also achieve a quasi-quant. anal. of the Co redox evolution in LiCoO2 based on the energy position of the spectroscopic peak. The benefit of multiplet calcns. is more important for studying electrode materials with TMs of mixed spin states, as exemplified by the quant. anal. of the mixed spin Na2-xFe2(CN)6 system. At the end, we showcase that such quant. anal. could provide valuable information for optimizing the electrochem. performance of Na0.44MnO2 electrodes for Na-ion batteries. The methodol. summarized in this review could be extended to other energy application systems with TM redox center for detailed anal., for example, fuel cell and catalytic materials.
